Question on the HubL |sort filter,
My understanding on it has always been if you sort an array like:

“B” “A” “C”
Result will be “ABC”

Now if you sort by a number, I thought it would sort numbers like how you’d count
“9” “10" “8”
Would sort as
“8" “9” “10"

I’m starting to think though, that is not how it functions and that instead it actually is going by the first character, then the second character etc.

So what you get instead is
“10” “8" “9”

which way is it *Supposed* to work?
basically i want to know how to sort numerically, and if my previous method was wrong
I imagine it would sort non-string numbers numerically, but if they're strings it'd sort them as strings
that makes sense
hmm… I may have a problem then
Or `|map('float')` if you expect decimals
would that  break if you had `{% set list = ["9", "8", "10", "word" %}`
`|int` turns anything it can't parse as a number into 0
So you'd get `[0, 8, 9, 10]`, I think
hmm
So yeah, if you need to sort mixed strings and numbers that's kind of a problem.
yea, gonna give my client just a checkbox and if they toggle that I do the map int sort trick
otherwise I’m expecting a string
Thank you for the help Ian!

I know i mentioned this last week, but we can get an additional option to have the blog listing pages include a self referencing canonical tag? Right now, I am basically going to be doing this myself via HubL but if the option is there for it, it would be nice. Right now, the options are set to none or to the first page which both are not recommended best practice
Does anyone work with modifying the title tag on pages through HubL?
for normal pages no, not usually a need to
and one last, you can use HubL tags in the JS Section of a CM right? for doing conditionals (like if statements). Sorry having a huge memory gap at the moment
#busybusyfriday
The JS Pane does not allow any hubl other than the assets hubl snippet
same applies to the CSS pane
ah perfect
the workaround is you can do things like use data attributes to essentially access those hubl vars and whatnot
The reason they don’t support hubl in the JS pane is because it would create hell when it comes to multiple instances of modules in the  page.

By any chance, is anyone else experiencing USER PERMISSION issues with the Web Page builder?

I’m Super Admin of my own account, but I’m suddenly NOT AUTHORIZED to update or publish website page. WTH
I haven’t heard of any issues. I’d recommend calling into support to see if they can troubleshoot
Thanks <@U22PKFRU5> - I tried calling in but since I’m on a Designer account, the automated system wouldn’t connect me to a human.

Ah, got it <@UA5DFM7CK> - yeah that’s annoying. Sorry, didn’t know it was a designer account. Live phone support is mega expensive for HubSpot, so we’re forced to point free accounts on forum support. 

I’ll DM you tho

Does anyone use multiple stylesheets for their sites? I can't find heavy documentation on it, I have a huge website, and thus a very big stylesheets that is affecting pageload and has multiple issues. On other sites I looked at, I don't see separation of stylesheets even though it's supported. Does putting module specific css into the module itself aid in this or create unnecessary inline/head styling? Any other suggestions to improve page load and css issues?

I use multiple stylesheets. HubSpot minifies it all so load time isn't an issue. I like separating out things. As for module css, I stick to as basic as possible so I can reuse in multiple portals. Themed styles go into the a stylesheets. Curious for other workflows
